Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2012 03:45PM C-squared wrote: Michelle~ I reversed the "standard of care" in my case and had neoadjuvant chemotherapy first.  The medical world would have liked to do mastectomy first but for my own reasons, I switched it around.  I was initially diagnosed at the end of November 2011 and didn't begin chemo until the 20th of January 2012.  I too was nervous that the cancer could have grown but am glad to share with you that in the end I am NED!  Good Luck to you.., you have come to a good place here at bco.org!  The information shared and support given has helped me through each step of the way!  I wish you peace and comfort, friendship and love!

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2012 01:47PM C-squared wrote: nibbana~Don't feel bad.., I fired my oncologist too.  It was one of the BEST things I ever did!  I no longer feel bad after an office visit.  Quite the contrary.., I feel truly supported like he's got my back!! Good for you for making the change.  We need information.  We also need to be heard, understood, supported and a part of the team / decision making process.  I hope your new oncologist is all that you hope for. Best wishes!
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2012 01:00PM C-squared wrote: I fired my oncologist because she wasn't at all like your oncologist.  I absolutely LOVE my new oncologist!  He is supportive, caring, compassionate, knowledgeable, collaborative, and has excellent bed-side manner.  He is genuine and I can feel it in the little things that he does.  For example, when I was admitted to the hospital at 3:00 a.m., he was there at my bedside at 8:00a.m. (the same morning!) When he received the results of my CT and PET scans yesterday, he called me in the evening to let me know the GOOD results (so I wouldn't have to sweat it until Monday).  The first time I met with him I was having a he*! of a time with AC.., after writing everything down for me and switching up a few meds. he gave me his cell phone number and directed me to call him the day after my next chemo and let him know how I was doing.  Maybe he goes above and beyond but the oncologist I "fired" would NEVER have done any of these things muchless make me feel like it was okay to ask questions and be collaborative in my treatment.   She accused me of "directing my own treatment" and that was our last meeting.  The first oncologist is somewhat new to the field and has a lot to learn.  Don't get me wrong, I truely believe we all have to start out new and I respect the learning curve..., it just wasn't a good mix.  In the end, I think we both learned something from it.  IMHO it is of the utmost importance that we have a medical team behind us that  makes us feel as if they've got our back. My new oncologist has my every body part and I am blessed to have his care!

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2013 02:37AM C-squared wrote: I think that SPAMgirl hit the nail right on the head when she said "nobody outside of this board will truly understand."  IMO, it is challenging enough for those of us who DO have cancer to TRULY understand what another person is experiencing.  If you think about it.., those who did not have chemo & perhaps only radiation, don't have a clue what chemo was like.., but they have breast cancer!   A lumpectomy is not the same as a mastectomy (obviously). And mets are not like Stage II. Pre-menopause and post-menopause are nowhere near each other.  Tamoxifen and AI's may bring us somewhat closer but still.  The differences are so abundant, it rarely ceases to amaze me!  Isn't that why we choose the boards that we associate with here on bc.org?  So we can relate to those who may TRULY understand.., with compassion and a true understanding. We seek to be validated and that is one of the many reasons bc.org is SUCH a great resource! I offer this perspective (as obvious as it may be to us) because we know that our loved ones, our  family, freinds, and neighbors are doing their best to comfort us and to support us.  Some want to be educated.., some "had no idea".  How many times has an ER+ woman been asked - "so will they be putting you on hormone replacement therapy?" And ya' just want to shake them & say "did you hear a WORD that I just said? Estrogen FEEDS my cancer!" But it makes you laugh because other-wise, you'll cry! I hope that I have not over-stepped my boundaries here.  I've noticed that (I think) all of the posts here come from women with Stage IV.  Quite honestly, I had a very limited concept of what dealing with Stage IV was like until my (32 yo) cousin taught me.  After all, I was a LE therapist working with breast cancer patients, so I "knew"..., AND I had alot of information to share with her. HA!  Then I asked her a VERY naive question (about having a mastectomy) and that's when I truly knew I was out of my league.  I should just LISTEN because I had lots more to learn!   Across the board, I think breast cancer is a humbling experience!  It re-aligns priorities, gives us new perspectives and provides a world of education we never signed up for! No need to feel guilty or to take on others' burdens.  Maybe we see the silver-lining a little more now.  Maybe we don't care about the "stupid" sh*t.  Maybe we know alot more about cancer than we ever expected. Not to be cliche but I think we laugh harder, we love deeper, and we LIVE each and every day because we want to live!

Posts.Content: May 18, 2013 06:57PM C-squared wrote: Hi ladies~ I need you support, prayers, optimistic thoughts, karma.., whatever it is that your comfortable with for a dear friend of mine (started out a s my very 1st LE patient, many, many years ago!) who was hospitalized this past Tuesday with a systemic blood infection (they believe was caused by her port as she has had it for many, many years).  She is having a difficult time coming out of sedation, no doubt conserving her energy to fight this infection.  Her BP initially dropped to 50/35, her temp was 102.5.  They have her on a mega-dose of antibiotics, and a breathing tube.  She had 3.5 litres of fluid removed from her abdomen (paracentisis) due to liver dysfunction and has had this done numerous times in the past. Her kidneys are barely functioning. I am so fearful that she is coming to the end of this awful journey though there is no talk of that from her husband.  She has 2 beautiful daughters age 9 and 12 who need their mother.  I'm wondering if I am way off base or if this is a legitimate concern (that she is nearing the end).  Can you please shed some of your wisdom on this for me?  I look forward to hearing from you.  Thank you!

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2012 01:30PM C-squared wrote: Hi all! I had my first AC today and I have a wicked headache!  Worse than the worst hangover I ever had (in my younger days). I've been on top of the meds since returning home (about 4pm, CST) and taken Ibuprofen, Zofran, Buspar (anti-anxiety), and LOTS of water as well as some Vitamin water.  I can't seem to shake the headache & I can't necessarily switch to Tylenol until the Ibuprofen wears off.  Any suggestions for when I CAN switch to Tylenol or something else that might work better?  I don't feel it's life-threatening so don't want to call the onc office at this hour (10:30pm).  You ladies probably know better anyway! Thanks!!

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2012 11:32AM C-squared wrote: Baldeagle & Cynthia~ It is my understanding that they DO use tumor markers more frequently in later stages as the reliability increases.  Certainly Baldeagle, you should have some scans for baseline information, if for nothing else.  My onc is not necessarily a true believer in running tests every three months (I am stage IIb) but I have had CTs (2), a PET, and a "baseline DEXA so far.  If you like your onc. you may not necessarily have to switch but a collaborative conversation may be beneficial.  If he/she still doesn't agree than you may need to look elsewhere.  The way I understand it, our oncologists will be with us forever.  I believe it's VERY important to have a good and trusting relaionship.  I am only 9 months out  from diagnosis and switched my oncologist after 5 months.  I am SO glad thatI did!!! Good Luck & keep us posted!

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2012 04:55PM C-squared wrote: MissC~ My situation is similar:  48 yrs old, Invasive Lobular, 3.5 cm., Stage IIb, ER/PR +/HER2-, Taxol followed by AC, BMX, No Rads - my understanding is that it depends upon the size of the tumor and # of Nodes involved.  I was glad to not have rads.., they have their own set of side effects and excess baggage.  Please feel comfortable to discuss these things with your Oncologist.  I took along a digital voice recorder to all appointments (oncology, general surgeon, plastic surgeon) so I could listen to and process the information at my own speed.  It's allot to take-in and it may take a while to understand and that's okay!  You may also want to look up the guidelines for breast cancer treatment at this website:  http://www.nccn.com/files/cancer-guidelines/breast/index.html  the National Comprehensive Cancer Network.

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2012 05:47PM C-squared wrote: MissC~ I would encourage you to find out what "guidelines" are followed in Ireland for breast cancer treatment.  Use the NCCN link that I sent you to formulate questions for your doctors (and do take along a tape or digital voice recorder) and take it from there.  There are so many factors involved in formulating an individual treatment plan.  There is no one-size-fits-all for breast cancer treatment so while we can all provide you with our individual experiences and treatment plans does not mean the plan will be the same for you.  Here's the link again...,  http://www.nccn.com/files/cancer-guidelines/breast/index.html  the National Comprehensive Cancer Network.  It's worth a look-see. Good Luck MissC & please, don't hesitate to advocate, advocate, advocate for yourself over there!!!
Posts.Title: Oncology consult and chemotherapy Waitingforthenextstep maa764

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2012 04:52PM C-squared wrote: bdavis- the NCCN is the Nat'l Comprehensive Cancer Network.  I'd never heard of it before being diagnosed either.  Apparently these are the guidelines that the oncologists office I go to follows.  I think that the oncs are following some form of structured treatment recommendations (do you know what they based the decision on for you?) -  i.e., I believe it is the NCI (Nat'l Cancer Institutes) that run the trails (not all but majority?), collect the data and form "standards" based on what has happened in the research stages.  It takes YEARS to develop treatment protocols although it seems to us like they're changing things all the time.., I'm not sure that they are changing the guidelines, I think the medical community is talking about what they are finding in the latest research trials.  But that's just a hypothesis on my part.  Bottom line, I believe I am in the "grey" area as well.  I plan to consult with a RO but I believe that they will recommend radiation so I'm just here looking for women (& men) with experience to shed some light on the subject so I can go in and ask some intelligent questions when I meet with the RO.  I do not believe there is any right or wrong when in the grey space.., I'm just trying to put it all together so I can make a decision while I have time.  Thanks for helping me along in the process. CC

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2012 06:35PM C-squared wrote: Sounds like I am in the same boat as some here.., weighing the pros and cons of radiation.  Like every step along the way this is a heavy decision for me.  I have seen what rads can do (burn and disfigure) to the skin and how it can ruin reconstruction.  I guess I need to hear the stats.  That said.., I truly believe in the theory that if you go to see a RO, they will recommend radiation..., but again, I need to hear the stats.  I know, as stated in an earlier post, that I am SO tired of hearing about the "standard of care" - they really don't talk about the after math, only the "standard" as dictated by the NCCN (at least that's what my onc uses).  As a matter of fact I had to ask my onc to recommend another physicican in the practice to see me because I was so tired of that response! (& other communication issues) but I digress. I have completed 7 rounds of Taxol & a lumpectomy.  I am currently receiving AC infusions- 1/4 complete.  My BMX is scheduled for July 5th and I need to make a decision so my PS knows which route to take with reconstruction.  {sigh}  Will this ever end?
